Award.AwardTitle: Identification and Characterization of Functional Constraints Operating on the Gene Organization of the Drosophila Genome

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will advance understanding of the relationship between the organization of genes on chromosomes and the probability of occurrence of macromutations that alter chromosomes. The organization of genes on chromosomes can be important for proper gene function, which sometimes requires the interplay of genetic factors far apart on the chromosome. Methods that enable the manipulation of fruit flies chromosomes will be used to test the consequences of induced rearrangements on the function of genes putatively under the influence of these long-range effects. This project aims at answering why particular regions of chromosomes have been conserved among distantly related species while others often exhibit an unusual association with macromutations.

Broader Impacts: From the training standpoint, this project will help train one postdoc, six undergraduates, and six high-school students in the analysis of the function of genomes and evolutionary biology. Members of underrepresented groups will be preferentially benefited by the research activities to be developed. Participants will also have the opportunity to hone their presentation skills. In addition, specific activities in this project will be adapted and integrated into the teaching activities of the PI. All data and materials generated will be made publicly available to the scientific community and deposited in appropriate repositories.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Through this award, we have attempted to understand the properties of genomic regions showing opposite dynamics of change based on their degree of conservation over evolutionary time.  Our main focus has been on chromosomal regions in which the internal gene order is virtually conserved across distantly related species.  We have done so in the genus Drosophila, which is characterized by a genome that undergoes recurrent repatterning via chromosomal inversions.  Conserved regions are considered to be under some sort of constrain that make them refractory to change given that those macromutations can exert detrimental effects through improper gene function.  To test this hypothesis, we adopted different approaches including the disruption of different ultraconserved regions and the comparative analysis of multiple arthropod genomes focusing on particular regions considered to be exposed to strong functional constraints such as the Tinman complex, which includes a set of important developmental genes that drive mesoderm development.  Our results depict a much more complex picture than previously thought, highlighting the extreme flexibility of the gene order along eukaryotic chromosomes.  For example, the Tinman complex was found to be heavily fragmented, showing up to four different gene arrangements along the chromosomes of different Drosophila species.  This suggests that gene clustering alone does not necessarily denote a selectively maintained organization.  This study also shows how distant regions on the same chromosome that colocalize in the nucleus of the cell might have an increased probability to reunite via chromosomal rearrangements, pointing to a mechanism through which clusters of similar genes can arise, beyond the commonly proposed mechanism of tandem duplication.  Further, we have performed a comprehensive characterization of the organization of ultraconserved blocks of genes that harbor stretches of high density of noncoding DNA, or HCNEs, using the existing wealth of functional and phenotypic data available in Drosophila.  These HCNE peaks are supposed to regulate gene expression of neighboring genes, being proposed as one of the mechanisms that preserve the conservation of gene organization among species.  One interesting finding is that in half of the conserved blocks of genes where the HCNE peaks reside, the genes present show no obvious hallmarks indicative of their association with HCNE peaks.  This suggests that current proxies for HCNE-target identification are not fully appropriate.  More recently, we have started the genomic characterization of several populations of a particular species, which is considered to harbor the most dynamic genome within the genus Drosophila, finding some degree of reproductive isolation among them.

We also tried to obtain a better understanding of the molecular organization and effects on the organism of a particular genomic region that is exclusive of the species Drosophila melanogaster.  This region, due to its properties (several copies with almost no nucleotide differences), has remained poorly characterized since the genome of Drosophila was sequenced.  We have found that this genomic region has a different number of copies and internal positioning relative to what is shown in public databases, highlighting how similar regions in other species can benefit from the use of new sequencing technologies.  Often, these regions are associated with conspicuous differences among individuals of the same species.  Lastly, we completed another research goal of our laboratory focused on deciphering the patterns of variation at the expression level of microRNAs both within and between species.  MicroRNAs are small RNA molecules that regulate the expression of 33% of the genes in eukaryotic genomes approximately, playing primary roles during developmental transitions and tissue differentiation.  MicroRNA evolution has been extensively studied at the sequence but not at the expression level.  By studying insect metamorphosis, we found multiple microRNAs that, although conserved at the sequence level both within and between species, displayed significant variation at the expression level.  Interestingly, the timepoints analyzed showed very different patterns and magnitude of variation in miRNA expression.

At the level of training, this award has been instrumental for exposing 25 undergraduate students (two of them subsequently becoming graduate students), one high-school student, one research assistant, and one postdoctoral fellow (now in a tenure-track position in an academic institution) to both cutting-edge and traditional approaches in genetics and genomics.  In addition, this exposure has helped lab members to consolidate their quantitative and computational skills.  Importantly, 17 undergraduates belonged to underrepresented groups (females, Latinos, or both), and 12 gained authorship on at least one of the seven peer-reviewed manuscripts published so far in the context of this award.  Further, one of our publications also has generated several new datasets, currently present in public repositories, facilitating their analysis by other colleagues.  Importantly, the research activity undertaken has generated materials that can be integrated by the PI in his teaching activities, which, depending on their success, will be shared with other instructors.  Lastly, this award has also fostered the collaboration with colleagues from seven academic institutions located in Australia, Canada, China, Denmark, Spain, UK, and USA.
